questions.question: Match the following conditions with their most commonly involved sites.
Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease?

options.A: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.explanation: Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of migration of the neural crest cells to the bowelwall.During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to the rectum. Theenteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells.In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to thedevelopment of a distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner (submucosal) and theAuerbach (myenteric) plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment.As a result, there is a lack of coordination in the peristaltic contractions and functionalobstruction, which further leads to the dilation of the intestine proximal to the affected segment,leading to congenital megacolon. Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the absence ofganglion cells in biopsy sections.1040Hirschsprung diseaseARAganglionicSegment(Contracted)OMARROWSome conditions may cause acquired megacolon. These include:•Chagas disease, due to the loss of ganglion cells• Visceral myopathy•Obstruction by neoplasm or inflammatory stricture• Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis• Functional psychosomatic disordersGanglionicSegment(Relaxed)

questions.question: A male infant, with a history of not passing meconium, presented with abdominal distension2 days after birth. Barium enema showed marked colonic dilation above a narrow segment inthe sigmoid region. A biopsy specimen from the narrowed region demonstrated absence ofganglion cells. This disease may be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. It is associated with Down's syndrome.Hirschsprung disease is also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon. 10% of all cases occur inchildren with Down's syndrome.The premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectumproduces aganglionosis of the distal intestinal segment. This causes functional obstruction of theaffected bowel and proximal dilation. The absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment inbiopsy confirms the diagnosis.1041Hirschsprung diseaseARAganglionicSegment(Contracted)OMARROWGanglionicSegment(Relaxed)Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Down's syndrome include:• Duodenal atresia• Annular pancreas• Hirschsprung diseaseGastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) include:• Meckel's diverticulum• MalrotationGastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) include:⚫ Omphalocele• Incomplete rotation of the colon• Meckel's diverticulum

questions.question: What is the most common site of volvulus?
questions.explanation: The most common site of volvulus is the sigmoid colon.The twisting of a loop of the bowel about its mesenteric point of attachment is termed volvulus.Segments involved in volvulus in the decreasing order of frequency are:•Sigmoid colon• Cecum• Small bowel• Stomach• Transverse colon1042

questions.question: What is the most common site of gastrointestinal ischemia?
questions.explanation: The most common site of gastrointestinal ischemia is the colon.Intestinal segments at the end of their respective arterial supplies are particularly susceptible toischemia. These are termed watershed zones. These include:••Splenic flexure - where the superior and inferior mesenteric arterial circulations terminate⚫ Junction of sigmoid colon and rectum - where the inferior mesenteric, pudendal, and iliacarterial circulations end

questions.question: Campylobacter infection can result in all of the following complications except:
questions.explanation: Aplastic crisis is associated with parvovirus infection, not Campylobacter infection.Campylobacter infection can cause:• Reactive arthritis, primarily in patients with HLA-B27.•Erythema nodosumGuillain-Barré syndrome (GBS)Molecular mimicry has been implicated in the pathogenesis of GBS because serum antibodies toCampylobacter jejuni lipopolysaccharide crossreact with peripheral and central nervous systemgangliosides.

questions.question: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological specimen from a patient withwatery diarrhea and abdominal pain. What is the most probable diagnosis?1035
questions.explanation: The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern ofmucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption.This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis.1043Clostridium difficile colitis0000Clostridium difficile colitisEmerging neutrophils(resembling volcano eruption)Superficiallydamaged cryptsIn this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficileovergrowth.Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are:•Antibiotic use• Advanced age• Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers• Immunosuppression

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presented with loose stools and right lower abdominal pain for the past 6months. Endoscopy was done which showed skip lesions with a cobblestone appearance.Histopathological examination showed aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses. Whichof the following genes is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: 1044The given scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease. It is strongly associated with mutations in thenucleotide oligomerization binding domain 2 (NOD2) gene.Crohn's disease occurs due to the host response against microbes. NOD2 encodes an intracellularprotein that binds to bacterial peptidoglycans and activates the NF-κB pathway. Antibodiesagainst the bacterial protein flagellin may be seen in NOD2-associated disease.Other Crohn's disease-related genes are autophagy-related 16-like (ATG16L1), andimmunity-related GTPase M (IRGM), which are critical for cellular responses to intracellularbacteria.Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum but can affect all parts of the GIT.The following microscopic changes may be seen:•Aphthoid ulcerations• Focal crypt abscesses• Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of the bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery,peritoneum, liver, and pancreasNote: Ulcerative colitis-associated genes are ECM1 and HNFA.

questions.question: An endoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with lower abdominal pain andsevere diarrhea. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?1036
questions.explanation: The given scenario along with cobblestone appearance on endoscopy is suggestive of Crohn'sdisease. This condition is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, not primary biliarycirrhosis.Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include the following:•Uveitis• Migratory polyarthritis• Sacroiliitis.Ankylosing spondylitis•Erythema nodosum• Clubbing of the fingertips•Primary sclerosing cholangitis (less frequently than ulcerative colitis)• Cutaneous granulomas form nodules referred to as metastatic Crohn's disease (a misnomer sincethere is no cancer)

questions.question: Which of the following gross findings would you see in the resected bowel segment of apatient with ulcerative colitis?
questions.explanation: In ulcerative colitis, regenerating mucosa often bulges into the lumen to create pseudopolyps andthe tips of these polyps may fuse to create mucosal bridges.Features characteristic of ulcerative colitis are:1045•Proctocolitis/ backwash ileitis• Mucosa and superficial submucosal involvement••• Broad-based ulcersPseudopolyps and mucosal bridges• Toxic megacolonNote: Granulomas, strictures, and mural thickening are features of Crohn's disease.

questions.question: p-ANCA is positive in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Henoch-Schönlein purpura is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the smallvessels, not p-ANCA.The following conditions are positive for perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies(p-ANCA):• Ulcerative colitis• Crohn's disease• Churg-Strauss syndrome•Microscopic polyangiitisAntibodiesP-ANCAAntibodies toSaccharomycescerevisiaeUlcerative colitisCrohn's diseasePresent in majority (75Present in minority (11%)%)AbsentPresent

questions.question: A pathology resident notes flask-shaped ulcers in an intestinal biopsy sample. This ischaracteristic of infections caused by which of the following?
questions.explanation: Flask-shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis, which is caused by Entamoeba histolytica.It most often affects the cecum and ascending colon. Parasites may also penetrate splanchnicvessels and embolize to the liver to produce amoebic liver abscesses.Image showing flask-shaped ulcers of amoebiasis:1046Amoebiasis - Flask shaped ulcerTRIMMEOption A: In TB, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers).Option B: In typhoid, ulcers are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers).Option C: Ulceration is not a feature of giardiasis.

questions.question: Microscopic colitis encompasses which of the following?
questions.explanation: Microscopic colitis encompasses two types of disorders - collagenous colitis and lymphocyticcolitis.Lymphocytic colitis shows a strong association between celiac disease and autoimmune diseases,including Graves disease and rheumatoid arthritis.These idiopathic diseases both present with chronic, non-bloody, watery diarrhea without weightloss.Collagenous colitisDense subepithelial collagen.layerIncreased numbers of intraepithelial lymphocytesLymphocytic colitisSubepithelial collagen layer is of normal thicknessHigher ratio of intraepitheliallymphocytes

questions.question: A 19-year-old boy with suspected acute appendicitis underwent laparoscopic appendectomyand the resected specimen was sent for histopathological examination. Presence of which ofthe following is considered confirmatory of this condition?

options.B: Neutrophilic infiltration of the muscularis propria
options.D: Eosinophilic infiltration of the muscularis propria

questions.explanation: The diagnosis of acute appendicitis is confirmed by the presence of neutrophilic infiltration ofthe muscularis propria.1047Surgical exploration is done when clinical suspicion for appendicitis is high but imaging studiesare negative, nondiagnostic, or unavailable. In such situations, appendicitis can only be diagnosedintraoperatively or pathologically.1048
